/COMMIT_MSG.message:
we had some discussion internally recenly about if ironic si supproted with host aggreates at all.

you add compute services to host aggreates not compute node via the api.

ironic shares multiple compute_nodes under one compute service.

we do not expect you to be able to add/remove indivigual compute node form an aggreate and with the current hashring behavior in the ironic driver that can move compute nodes between compute serivces its not clear that supprot ironic today is safe.


we need to think about this carefully before proceeding with this.

nova/compute/api.py.message: we decided a while ago to restrict ironic support for placement aggregates to map the existing nova behaviour, which was to have one compute as as host...

... accordingly, accepting this patch would create a behavioural difference between the semantics of a nova aggregate and a placement aggregate (in terms of automatical mapping).

Nobody prevents you to create another placement aggregate and add all the node-related Resource Providers but here we're discussing of changing an existing behaviour and I personnally feel this discussion should occur as a feature design and not as as bugfix.

the primary differnt between placment and nova aggreates is captuures in the placment api ref

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/#delete-resource-provider-inventory

although i find it simpler to read here
https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/master/api-ref/source/aggregates.inc

the imporant part is 
```
* In Nova, a host aggregate associates a *nova-compute service* with
  other nova-compute services. Placement aggregates are not specific
  to a nova-compute service and are, in fact, not
  compute-specific at all. A resource provider in the Placement API is
  generic, and placement aggregates are simply groups of generic
  resource providers. This is an important difference especially for
  Ironic, which when used with Nova, has many Ironic baremetal nodes
  attached to a single nova-compute service. In the Placement API,
  each Ironic baremetal node is its own resource provider and can
  therefore be associated to other Ironic baremetal nodes via a
  placement aggregate association.
```
  
as it stand today we expect you to be able to add the ironic compute serivces to nova host aggreate 
but we do not expect the placement-mirror-host-aggregates feature to map all the compute nodes managed by that service to the pacment aggreate.
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/rocky/implemented/placement-mirror-host-aggregates.html

supprot for ironic compute node maping to placment aggreates wwas out of scope fo that. change.


so if we want to supprot automatic mirroign of the compute node rps for ironic that is a behavioral cahnge as sylvain noded.

i do think there is merit in supporting host-aggreates with ironic and with palcement mirroring but  this would be a new feaure.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: nice work!

I think back when we were SUPER skeptical about sharding first rolling out we really wanted a checkpoint where we have injected shard ranges into one of the roots, and they've fully replicated to all the nodes - but no one is trying to CLEAVE yet (basically a "do no harm" approach)

... then we manually ran the sharder or added the enabled metadata or something

basically we made what could be a single state transistion in the distributed model into a multi-phase commit; but we never really implemented the rollback because we now mostly just love sharding - GO GO GO!  I think we can collapse unsharded -> sharding_initiated -> sharding into a single pass of the replicator, and should mostly head that direction after we find a quick/safe fix for this failing probetest.

This is rough, but we could do something like this.. The probe test now fails (haven't fixed it). I seem to get a 409 conflict, which might be the delete failing because it now isn't considered deleted.  But ran out of time so havne't looked into it.

I forgot to drop these comments last week.  I think the strategy seems sane, but the connection plumbing changes are intrusive and inconsistent - they seem like an orthogonal optimization.

I'd like to see a re-spin with passing tests.

I know that we want to get is_deleted to respond false in the sharder when a root with a delete timestamp still has shard ranges with objects in them

I don't know how to reconicle the difference between db_state and the osr.state wrt to alternate object counts - and the tests are trying to tell us we don't have a clear model for how that works - we need to make it LESS complex

... but we definately need to at least have PASSING tests https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/848776
I took an alternative approach here https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/848962

i'm realizing some of the connection plumbing may have been in response to the weirdness with in-memory databases that popped up for me working on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/848780
yeah, I found it out the hard way when testing in-memory brokers. Fun times. I'll take a look at yours.

swift/container/backend.py.message: this seems like a subtle difference, the public method does some extra queries - so i'm guessing this is just an optimization since we only need the osr.state

Yeah, we only need toe curent state. Also the public method call will call get_info to get object states which calls get_alternate_obj_states which calls sharding_initiated (as of this patch), so gives us recursion loop. BUT we don't care abount the current calculated stats we just want the state (and ranges).

"sharding_initiated" seems like reason enough to return the summed up shard usage - the is_deleted method doesn't even look at the value of the returned state

heck; does it *really* need to be conditional at all?  If we have active shard ranges telling us they have objects in them - are we really deleted?  I don't think so... unless we have stale shard_range state?  but that'd be a different bug.

Interesting thought. I know Al was under the impression, if we're in the UNSHARDED state we should not look elsewhere.

The sharding_initiated is looking at the OSR state, and if so checks to see if there are shardranges, but it's an any non-deleted shardrange not just ACTIVE ranges.

So we have 2 state machines. This is currently looking at the DB state machine. sharding_initiated is looking at the OSR one. When the DB state is SHARDING we have 2 brokers on disk, and we want to look at the metadata in the old broker. 

If we are in the UNSHARDED DB state, but OSR is in SHARDING then can we trust the shards we have to give us the "correct enough" details? In theory the FOUND will have the object_counts from the initial find, but currently those in the CREATED state can be 0'ed if the sharder gets to them, that is until (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/837811) lands.
But having said that, I'm not sure we're tracking the byte_count, so the states aren't necessarily correct when ranges state < ACTIVE.

Arguably, in the case of what we are trying to fix, _ANY_ object in a shardrange means it can't be deleted, so loosening the stats belt make sense in that situation. But that about at other times when we want to most up to date stats.

Maybe it needs to be:

 - SHARDING: Look at old broker
 - SHARDED: Look at shards
 - UNSHARDED: Look at self (object table), unless OSR is in SHARDED state, at which case the shards should be "active" enough to be the source of knowledge?
FWIW, it's still making two connections
i think this is the begining of the connection plumbing
we might call this state 'SHARDED (initiated)' or something

UNSHARDED from get_db_state is something like:

only one db, and it doesn't have an epoch

... but if the osr is sharded by another node, and has already shipped us shard ranges... this is the state we're interested in, sharding-initiated-but-unstarted - THAT state, OR "SHARDED" state should return the extra shard_usage for the purpose of answering "is_deleted" at a minimum

why not go ahead and plumb connection re-use through here too?  next call is get_shard_ranges

why don't we need to check is_root_container?

I think this is the bottom of the connection re-use plumbing

_get_shard_range_rows always accepted a connection kwarg and put it through swift.common.db.DatabaseBroker.maybe_get

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
I do wonder in retrospect, if we need to take into account some kind of:

  state == UNSHARDED and broker.get_shard_ranges()

too? Or will a unsharded root with shardranges, but not have any objects be ok.. maybe they will.. just a thought while I was cooking. Haven't thought it out but wanted to put it somewhere.
I find it really questionable that a broker with shard ranges and objects can return True from is_deleted - that method should know better.

I'm with Clay - unless I have forgotten a gotcha, it strikes me that if a broker with *sharding enabled* and shard ranges with non-zero object count should return is_deleted() == False just like it would if it had object rows.

In fact, maybe there should be a unit test somewhere that asserts that brokers in different db_state, but otherwise consistent state, are consistent in their is_deleted() return values.

That said, we might want to be careful about changing when brokers start using shard ranges object counts for the broker info (_get_alternate_object_stats()) - while the db is UNSHARDED we might still want to use the db object count (as master does now).

So, IDK, maybe ContainerBroker._get_alternate_object_stats() should have a clause like

  if state == UNSHARDED and stats['object_count'] == 0:
      stats = self.get_shard_usage()

this is *incredible* - so not only is the "fix" as simple as just letting the sharder process the "deleted" broker.  That "unsharded" broker has enough state replicated from the other nodes to completly heal the system to a consistent state if we let it.

I think this proves it's fundementally wrong for that "deleted" database to say its "unsharded" once it's recieved the sharding state from it's peers.
it seems maybe it IS at least "sharding_initiated" which should be a subset of "sharding" which is definately NOT "unsharded" (so not-un means *is* ... SHARDED).  QED
Not sure this probetest is working with the new code yet. If the new code works the replica with shards wont be "deleted" anymore if we have shards with objects. So will need to adjust.

swift/container/backend.py.message: i'm glad to see the subtle return unpacking gone here
oic, this is the only method that "needed" state returned from alternate_stats
it turns out that the caller that did not previously need this key in the returned dict also does not care if is present...so we can just add it always
IIUC we definitely do not want shard containers to report their shard range stats once they have SHARDED (which could be due to sharding or shrinking)
Oh yeah, good call
apart from the refactoring, this is the only behavioural change

@Clay: in the past we decided that when a db is UNSHARDED or SHARDING the most sensible indication of object count was the (retiring) DB: while cleaving, objects are not removed from the retiring DB so it continues to report its historic object_count; there's no sure way of knowing that the shards object counts are more accurate than the retiring DB at this point[*]. Once sharded we flip to use the shards' object counts, knowing that all of the db's rows have been cleaved so the shards' object counts will be at least the retiring db object count - but we only do this for root containers - sharded shards should always be considered empty.

I am preserving that behaviour except for when the retiring DB object count is zero (when we see the bug) - in this case if the shard ranges have non-zero object count then this *is* better info than we have from the retiring DB, so we'll now use that.

A COLLAPSED db by definition has no shard ranges.

([*] on reflection, it could be argued that we should always use the greater of retiring db object count or shards' object count.)

why the state condition and not object_count?

NOTFOUND = 'not_found'
UNSHARDED = 'unsharded'
SHARDING = 'sharding'
SHARDED = 'sharded'
COLLAPSED = 'collapsed'

... did the tests about "object_count should be zero" have something to do with these:  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/848776/1

... I think there's *obviously* cases where we're returning object_count=0 today and that's just WRONG - at a minimum, for the purposes of "is_deleted", I can't see a good justification that it's MOST correct to ever say yes if there's object count in either misplaced objects OR in the shard ranges table.  I'm not sure how much we should let the complexity of the sharding state machine trample on that basic fact.

I guess the sharder does still try and deal with misplaced objects if the container is deleted, so it should "undelete" itself once it's dealt with any rows in the object table that are misplaced.. so maybe that part is ok. Not sure about the reconiler though.

From the time I spent on this last week I do now have a worry that our "is_deleted" is very flakey. The _is_deleted even mentions that is only is looking at the one spi. does this mean if there were objects in the wrong policy in the container, we can decide we're deleted. what happens to the reconciler, does this lead to dark data?

Further, what if we're sharded and our shards have no objects (great) but there are some misplaced objects in our object table.. then we have objects don't we?

The more I think about this, the more I want to make the _is_deleted simple. If there are objects in any policy in the object table (really that's just checking the policy stat table) or objects in the shards_ranges (for the states Al mentions) then we have objects and so can't be deleted.
This means we bail on thinking it's deleted and leave it to the consistency engine to fix it, be it sharding, reconciling or whatever.

BUT I only want this on the _is_deleted check, not normal stats.. because as stats go, I think we do then need to looks for the right places when in different states.
Oh this looks much cleaner.

So sharding appears twice. So to get here, this info check on the next line is actaully looking at the object_count of the retiring db. And only if that is 0.. I guess that's fine, in 99% of cases we're sharding a container.

If we're repairing a DB then it "could" be empty I guess, it'll be cleaving into a acceptor, which might not be able to happen if deleted. but this seems like such a niche case.. yeah I think this is fine

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
I agree this change could be a solid option, and it might have been great to have a month ago so we could have drained those nodes already without having to get distracted by the in-memory database connection stuff - but IMHO it's the wrong fix and I wouldn't yet recommend merging it.

I think matt and I had agreed: if a database has shard ranges with object count in them - it's not deleted (doesn't matter what timestamps say) - same goes for object rows both at the same time always!  You don't get to pick and choose when you follow the rules - the is_deleted function has a bug.  I'm not sure yet what the consequences of fixing that bug will be...

There's maybe another question of if the sharder truely has nothing to do when a database is deleted or if the replicator truely has nothing to do if a database is sharded... but add additional conditionals seems like ADDING complexity.

The fundamental bug is that our sync engine (combination of replicator and sharder) is not bringing replicas into sync. The fix here solves that by un-stalling the sharder.

However, I agree that all replicas already have sufficient state to make a consistent decision, and the ideal fix would be to make the replicas appear to be consistent sooner by making is_deleted() consistent across replicas. I just put this up because the other patches seem to be sprawling and this might be a useful tactical alternative.

I'll keep digging into https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/848780 too.

cinder/volume/api.py.message:
we are just updating the volume status to error here which doesn't seem like a proper cleanup. While creating a bootable volume from image, the volume could be attached to the controller node hence having an attachment record which we should take into account. Also the image is first downloaded into the image_conversion_dir which could have data copied to the dir and is not cleaned up here resulting in space consumption by a stale file. Also just to mention we also have to consider the image cache entry in this.
I would recommend going through the operation of creating a bootable volume from image and think of possible cases that should be cleaned up if we plan to delete the volume at any stage.

- We also want the capability to replicate role specific parameters or resources. 

- We might want to make the command work based on templates instead of the exported stack data, because what we basically need to tweak is the environment files and the role file.

> As I mentioned in irc, one concerning point is that some client like nova doesn't accept OS_CLOUD. Because I was checking this in stable/train so the situation might be different in master but we should be aware of that limitation.

Adding @Abhishek to confirm status for glance client, i heard it do not work with OS_CLOUD. same can be checked for other clients

Good catch.

Legacy clients like glanceclient does not work with OS_CLOUD and requires legacy environments.

```
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ printenv | grep OS_
OS_CLOUD=overcloud
PS1=${OS_CLOUD:+($OS_CLOUD)} [\u@\h \W]\$ 
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ glance image-list
You must provide a username via either --os-username or env[OS_USERNAME]
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ nova list
ERROR (CommandError): You must provide a user name/id (via --os-username, --os-user-id, env[OS_USERNAME] or env[OS_USER_ID]) or an auth token (via --os-token).
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ cinder list
OS Password: ... terminating cinder client
```

The reason why we are restoring this is that the early feature gap for nova/cinder has been improved but glanceclient might be a next blocker for complete migration for openstack CLI.

In the very early version of tracing (before there was even OpenTracing) this decorator just captured entry and exit time, ie it was used for "benchmarking" functions, which is how this all started.

Now that we have spans and span releated context managers, which also by default give us timing. Maybe we don't need this anymore.

I think we need to mention the BZ number in the commit message to make it clear why.

Here's the missing back story for train:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2144483 
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/865175/
  
and related:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2149339
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/865206/
  
The above resolved the BZ for train only. How do we solve it for main branch and newer?

> i assume it is because you want the cephadm logs for ceph deployment to be separate?

No, the idea is to have smaller log files which are eventually deleted as related to the bug above.

> is it possible to redirect the output of the ceph deploy to its own file then instead of creating a backup of ansible.log. The separation is not really clear like this.

Separation of ansible log runs related to different services (e.g. ceph, nova, cinder, etc.) is not the goal.

> I mean we have file1 with everything before ceph and then file2 with everything after (including any non ceph stuff that comes after the ceph deploy right?)

It's not about the ceph run. It's about unbound growth of the ansible.log file.

The utils function run_ansible_playbook() can get an optional parameter to rotate the ansible log file before it's called. Any caller of the function may then chose to use it. It assumes there's a cron job to clean up older versions of that file like https://review.opendev.org/865175 

This patch applies to the "ceph before overcloud" scenario. The "ceph during overcloud" scenario has been addressed already with this:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/867232
  
I don't expect the "ceph before overcloud" scenario to generate a lot of logs but in theory I thought this patch could apply the same pattern for ceph and provide a more general solution.

thanks for extra info. imo we should at least have Related-Bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2144483 in the commit message then

also, i was thinking about this from the point of view of a ci job, i.e. we'll have two ansible.log files to check now in the jobs

but really this is a fix for production where the ansible.log might be from deployment, then it is appended for any day two operations and keeps growing.

This can't be done because the parameter is managed by the base nova class. Defining the same parameter causes duplicated resources and prevents usage of nova and nova::api in the same manifest.

Also, the parameter is added to the global nova.conf which is read by all services so having this parameter in the api class does not make very clear sense.

We probably need a new parameter in nova which affects only api service, or can consider introducing a service specific config file such as nova-api.conf, but that requires change in nova or basic design change in puppet to support service specific configuration.

Hello, Sean

We've implemented a separate driver because we have next specific item in our solution:
1. We have the next path to the socket: /usr/local/var/run/ and the socket name has the next configuration: stdvio + vf number. So for example, if we use PCI with virtual function 6 ( 0000.2b00.6 ) we will have socket name stdvio6
You can see implementation of that here:
https://github.com/napatech/linkvirt-ovs-openstack-plugin/blob/main/networking_napatech/mech_linkvirt_ovs.py#L62

/COMMIT_MSG.message: it's
This patch adds a cron job to purge timestamped ansible logs from /home/stack but only if the deployer sets PruneOldAnsibleLogsInHome true (it defaults to false).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I'm really not a big fan of this kind of things. IMHO, the operator is able to clean things when they see fit, and as a general thought, we shouldn't temper with a user directory content - even if it's for log cleaning. There are so many possibilities to make a mistake, or to lose data....

I know the default is set to "false" - but now consider:
an operator sets the variable to true, makes tons of deploys, and think they want to actually keep one log, and rename it to ansible-keep-<date>.log (well, why not, right?)
It will be removed once the time is passed.

One example among others.

I won't block the proposal. But I won't vote for it either.

Since we're concerned about the risk of deleting user data, maybe this patch should be abandoned in favor of a docs patch to the following:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/deployment/ansible_config_download.html#ansible-project-directory

under ansible.log add that a date can be appended after ansible runs (per review 867336) but that it can purged with a find command and provide an example find command.

When reviewing this you may compare it to the following:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/865175/5/deployment/logrotate/logrotate-crond-container-puppet.yaml

I will abandon this patch considering the complications.

during 'openstack overcloud ceph deploy', review 867336 rotates /home/stack/ansible.log  but not the one in config-download path.

As discussed, we can update the documentation once ansible log rotation code is made available for 'openstack overcloud deploy' which updates ansible logs in config-download path.

deployment/logrotate/logrotate-crond-con.message:
Perhaps replace "Enable/disable deletion of old anisble logs in /home directory" with

"When true, a cron job will be installed which deletes ansbible.log-TIMESTAMP files from the Ansible project directory under $HOME/overcloud-deploy/<stack>/config-download."

I'd rather not put the code at all in the file if we don't want to prune the old ansible logs. Making it as a standard {% if PruneOldAnsibleLogsInHome|bool %}...{% endif %} would allow a cleaner generated file.

Nit:

Is /home/stack stored in a variable we should use here instead?

99% of the time it will be /home/stack but...

For standalone deployments StandaloneHomeDir should have it.
For production deployments UndercloudHomeDir should have it.

I wonder if we want get_param both and use ansible's ternary filter

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/devel/collections/ansible/builtin/ternary_filter.html

Actually let's set StandaloneHomeDir/UndercloudHomeDir aside and do better.

I think it's more correct to run this command not in /home/stack but in the config-download working directory within /home/stack. 

TripleO has more direct ownership of that directory (it's system, not person managed). In a standalone deployment it will get a name like standalone-ansible-m57b0n01. But I wonder if there's a Heat var we can use to determine in.

In a non-standalone production deployment its path is described here:

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/deployment/ansible_config_download.html#ansible-project-directory

Since running 'openstack overcloud deploy' commands will usually result in the working directory changing I think have a cron job prune that directory but not everything in /home/stack less controversial.

Hard pass from me at this point -- in the discussion of https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/87389 and related fixes, there was definitely some consideration of putting the fix up in urllib.parse (!!): https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/93879#issuecomment-1157339176

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: ugh, did you crib this from somewhere?  there's so many crazy things you can put into a url I have no idea how to infer if your tests cover everything that might make this blow up.

OK so partiion witll _always_ return 3 values, and if they are empty be empty strings not null. So we can always happily move to [2]:

  >>> path = b"https://"
  >>> host, sep, rest = path.partition(b'//')[2].partition(b'/')
  >>> host
  b''
  >>> sep
  b''
  >>> rest
  b''

OK, starting to like this partition approach.

But we've already split off the query string etc, so the path is just the path or potentually the full URL ending at the end of the path. So we could just use urlparse like:

  if path.startswith((b'http://', b'https://')):
      path = urlparse(path).path

But I guess that means we need to use urlparse and we already use partition just above so have precident.

Hmm, seems urlparse also supports not having a full url:

  In [2]: from urllib.parse import urlparse
  In [3]: urlparse('/somepath?q=a')
  Out[3]: ParseResult(scheme='', netloc='', path='/somepath', params='', query='q=a', fragment='')

And already supports byte strings:

  In [5]: urlparse(b'/')
  Out[5]: ParseResultBytes(scheme=b'', netloc=b'', path=b'/', params=b'', query=b'', fragment=b'')
  
So if we're happy with using urlparse and whatever that means for py2 support (I think it moved or something right). Then we could actually just swap lilke 441 with something like:

  parsed_url = urlparse(parts[1])
  path = parsed_url.path
  query = parted_url.query

And be done with it.
partition() doesn't blow up -- that's part of why I chose it. sep or rest may be blank, but they'll all be byte strings.

I don't know that I trust stdlib to be/stay sane. If we *do* go with stdlib, we want urlsplit, not urlparse -- I know I've been bit by that before. But I just spent the last hour being gaslit by docs before coming across https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/91708

At least with direct (byte) string manipulations, I actually know what's going on.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: From what I understood, the main change in this review is that "cert_bytes.decode('utf-8')" is no longer executed as the method "get_public_bytes(cert)" was removed. Probably this decoding was causing "pem_cert" to not be found in "pem_contents" and consequently not removed. The difference between CentOS and Debian may be the python version (python2 vs python3).

Yes, the root cause seems to be that in python 2.x 'bytes' was just an alias for 'str', and now is really a different type, so the 'replace' was comparing different types. manila/share/manager.py.message: access rules are being sent to the driver here with the assumption that they will be applied..
Looks like this logic needs to handle updates to individual access rules as well..

This call is unnecessary since the driver is expected to deal with access rules sequential to the creation of the replica: 

https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/73848870a5811d42fbd04f6e43efa3c78e037b82/manila/share/driver.py#L1876-L1879


or, the driver can ignore the rules if they don't apply (for example, with 'dr' style of replication); the rules are provided again during the promotion: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/73848870a5811d42fbd04f6e43efa3c78e037b82/manila/share/driver.py#L2137-L2138


So I think we should change the "queued_to_apply" state of the individual access rules to "active" in the "else" block above (Line 2392). It's possible there are rules that don't get applied eventually (i.e., invalid rules), we could allow the driver to tell us which ones in the "create_replica" and "promote_replica" operations.. something along these lines:

     reported_access_rules_status = replica_ref.get('access_rules_status')
     if reported_access_rules_status in (None, "active"):
            # update all rules to "active"
            conditionally_change = {'queued_to_apply': 'active'}
            self.access_helper.get_and_update_share_instance_access_rules(
                context, share_instance_id=share_replica['id'],
                conditionally_change=conditionally_change)
            # update "access_rules_status" on the replica
            self._update_share_instance_access_rules_state(
                context, share_replica['id'],
                constants.STATUS_ACTIVE)
     elif replica_ref.get('share_access_rules'):
           # driver would like to update individual access rules
           share_access_rules_dict = {rule['id']: rule for rule in share_access_rules}
           for rule_update in replica_ref.get('share_access_rules'):
               self.access_helper.get_and_update_share_instance_access_rule(
                   context, 
                   rule_update['id'], 
                   {'state': rule_update['state']},
                   share_instance_id=share_replica['id'])
               share_access_rules_dict.pop(rule_update['id'])
           if share_access_rules_dict:
              for rule in share_access_rules_dict:
                  self.access_helper.get_and_update_share_instance_access_rule(
                   context, 
                   rule_update['id'], 
                   {'state': 'active'},
                   share_instance_id=share_replica['id'])
            self._update_share_instance_access_rules_state(
                context, share_replica['id'],
                replica_ref.get('access_rules_status'))

We should account for cases on the nova side when we've extended the volume and fail after that, then nova needs to rollback the size since we can't/don't do anything on cinder side but it's a nova spec detail.

I'm not sure what you mean.

With an FS driver, Nova will send os-extend_volume_completion(error=True) if anything goes wrong.

With other drivers, an error in Nova does not impact the success of the extend operation (it might just mean that the instance can only access the volume at it's old size) and there is no need to rollback.

If Nova fails to call os-extend_volume_completion then there isn't a lot we can do, unfortunately.
An admin will have to reset the volume status and retry the resize.
That answers all my questions thanks.
move this to L#136 with the paragraph related to this.

I'm even more confused now. if cinder is going to call the `extend_volume_completion`, why do we need a new microversion and a new `os-extend_volume_completion` volume action?
It only makes sense if nova calls it.
Also we don't know when nova will complete the extend or if it will complete it successfully or not after it accepts the event. If nova fails and we extend the size here, it doesn't look like a good case.
IMO nova should be the one calling this new volume action via REST API like we do for migrate volume completion

Of course Nova calls the os-extend_volume_completion action, as described in the "Nova" subsection!

The paragraph you are commenting on describes the "VolumeManager.extend_volume()" method using the "VolumeManager.extend_volume_completion()" method to rollback when it can't submit the event to Nova.

What is missing in the spec is the following:
If no such error is encountered, then the event has been successfully submitted to Nova, and we can expect Nova to respond.
The "VolumeManager.extend_volume()" method will now return normally.
The Volume will be left in status "extending", until Nova eventually responds with the os-extend_volume_completion action.

This part of the behavior was left out because it felt obvious to me, which it isn't, of course. 
Sorry about that!
I will update this subsection to make this explicit.

I tried tried to reword that paragraph to make that more clear.

It is indeed Cinder calling extend_volume_completion here.

The external events API is asynchronous, but it respond 200 if the events are accepted.
It also has error responses like 403 and 404, and if we receive something like that, Cinder should not wait for a callback from Nova but should rollback the operation.

do you mean the volume_metadata?
I think there is no point to keep this info in admin metadata if we are going to make it visible for nova/end-users so we can just mention volume metadata instead of visible admin metadata.
sounds reasonable.

The concern is that the regular metadata is editable by users.
If a malicious user is fast enough, they could edit the target size before Nova resizes the volume, thus bypassing their quota.
I added that reasoning to the section.
what about ``extend_new_size``?

The main concern here was that unresolved quota reservations could block the user from using their full quota until they expire.

The metadata keys themselves shouldn't do any harm, and will be overwritten and then cleaned up when the resize is retried.
I have changed the section so that both keys are now removed from the admin metadata by os-reset_status.

I understand the reason to remove extend_reservations but even keeping extend_new_size might confuse operators as to why it suddenly exists in their volume and keeping it doesn't do us any benefit.
Marking as resolved as this is changed.
+1. This is out of the scope of the feature we're trying to implement but this is much cleaner than nova relying on volume metadata fields which then again needs to be visible by non-admins.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I have a probe test the shows these false positives which I'll then use to work at stopping the false positives, I'll push the probe test up in a new patchset.

Might have a play with the fixing in a follow up or seperate patch (at least for now) as this one is including in our prod downstream.

OK I've been looking back at the original incidents we had when we have a epochs reset on us. And in all the cases the OSR state was ACTIVE, the epoch was None and there was a state_timestamp.

That last one is actually very interesting. I delved back into the sharding statemachine. The default OSR makes the state_timestamp None and the only times we set the state_timestamp is when we move to SHARDING, SHRINKING or setting the epoch. This means that the "reset" epoch isn't simply a default OSR. But also means we have a way of detecting the false positives.

A shard OSR (which always exists in a shard) will be ACTIVE, have an epoch of None and a state_timestamp of None. But it'll also share a timestamp with that of it's replicas, as the timestamp shouldn't change unless we change deleted, name, upper or lower.
This means I can simply _not_ throw the warning if the replica OSR shard range has the same timestamp and has no state_timestamp. It means it's just an ACTIVE shard range that hasn't got its epoch yet.

Along these lines, I can do something like: https://paste.opendev.org/show/815286/

Which contains:

  if shard['name'] == osr['name'] and shard['epoch'] is None:
      # state_timestamp is only set when marking for sharding, shrinking
      # or setting an epoch. Therefore we can make an assumption:
      # 1. if shard has the same timestamp, then it's a replicas version
      #    of the OSR (not a new default); and
      # 2. If the state_timestamp is still None, then it's still just
      #   an ACTIVE shard OSR
      # If both those cases are true, then it's just another OSR replica
      # that hasn't moved to sharding yet, so we can safely ignore
      # without firing off a warning
      if not (osr['timestamp'] == shard['timestamp'] and
               not shard['state_timestamp']):
           logger.warning('Ignoring remote osr w/o epoch: %r, from: %s',
                          shard, source)
      continue

Sure enough when I add this code to this patch the new false positive probetests start to fail (there are no false positives).

Now that we know that, we might be able to just update the patch, which should remove the false positives and we can get back to monitoring for the warning to see if we actually every trigger the bug again. OR we could move this same logic into merge_shards and have a "fix" inside the broker.
this seems to be helping in prod with the associated bug, I'd like to see it merged if that makes sense

The idea here was to only block merging if the remote's epoch is None and the local isn't. Having a rempte epoch and None and a local is totally valid and what shards use. If we remove it shards will not merge each others OSRs which we may need to keep state up to date.

yeah, thought being if we have a new PUT to a handoff or new primary and a new container database is created it's ROWID will start at 0 right? An old primary will have a ROWID much bigger, which may trigger an rsync-then-merge. We rsync it to tmp (the new_broker), then pull in the shard ranges from the existing broker (in this case the new one). And we'd get the same problem.

However, the old primary is SHARDED so maybe the rsync-then-merge wont be triggered. I'll have to double check this. Either way it was a safety to make sure I filtered in all _possible_ places outside of the merge_shards.
so this is the container-server-rpc; when we're pushed new shard ranges
not covered by unit tests
Yup, so we sync both ways on every replication.
might be worth adding broker.db_path to the warning?

This tends to catch a lot of false-positives, where we initiate sharding on one replica (usually a shard), then the other replicas trip this warning even though the state timestamps should keep us from actually dropping the epoch. Alistair had an idea this morning to reduce the noise: only emit the warning if the epoch we're overwriting is older than (now - an hour) or something.

I'm kind of tempted to come at it from merge_shards() instead, with something like https://paste.opendev.org/show/baqD3bolWr4Wu41UIZnA/ -- though that breaks a couple unit tests.

Not a bad idea, but you *can* derive it together from what's logged: pass the name from the shard dict to swift-get-nodes to get the part/suffix/hashdir.

Even more useful (I think): add broker.get_own_shard_range(), so we can see what we're trying to merge *into* and how merge_shards() is failing us. It seems like we must have

 shard['state_timestamp'] > broker.get_own_shard_range()['state_timestamp']

but I'm not *at all* clear on how that could be the case...
Thats an interesting idea. Yeah, the way we auto shard where we are controller driven caused alot of false positives. Time based might work. I'll have a play.

Tim, I do like the merge_shards approach. I think I had a version like this early on. Let me take a closer look and see if that makes more sense.

I do like that we can compare the timestamps, because in theory one of the these "non epoch maybe default OSRs" should have a later timestamp, which is why the stomp all over existing ones.

I actually think this part of the change is completely unrequired. Looked back at the code, and rsync_then_merge will NOT happen if sharding or sharded locally. If an rsync and then merge happens then it'll be aborted if the remote is sharding. So this code isn't required. I might just revert this part.

> if sharding or sharded locally

but if osr is None; would it even *know* that it's sharding or sharded locally?  let's leave it for belts and braces and consistency

If the local side (ie not opposite side of the RPC) has a broker.sharding_initiated() it'll sync shard ranges and leave it to the sharder to deal.
Like you mention, which is the local is a None epoch, or moreso a default OSR, this will not be sharding_initated. But to be a candidate for rsync_then_merge the local needs to be have a higher object ROWID to qaulify (https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/db_replicator.py#L514). Which shouldn't be the case if it was a small handoff or what not. But let's be devil's avocate for a second and say it does, then it first pulls the remote shard ranges which should make the OSR in a sharding state, unless the remote OSR is < Local OSR in which case it'll:

  - It'll rsync the local DB over to tmp. 
  - On the RPC side of rsync_then_merge it'll do a self._abort_rsync_then_merge which does check to see if the RPC is broker.sharding_initiated() and if so abort.

So there is a server side check. It's kinda annoying that it'll rsync then check and fail. We do send back the db_state in the replication info, so we should do a check for that and abort _before_ sending a db, but this edgecase does seem pretty small.

*if* it's newer - that's the second time that came up in test comments - is the unintuative behavior desirable enough to preserve or simply an observation of how the system works currently?

Yeah, it's the current crux of the bug I think. We always merge newer (like the rest of swift). But a default OSR is brand new, so timestamp == Timestamp.now() which is newer the the old OSR.

If it the default was older then it'll just merged away.

This is to test the other code path, but also to test the bad node when pushing it's badness nothing happens to the good nodes. If the default OSR is older then things are OK, the remote shard_range sync will override it. Again it's a crux of the problem.. somehow a broker gets out there without an OSR so a default one is created and written to the broker.. because it's newer it overwrites all the "good" ones.

Another fix would be to make the default OSR have a timestamp of Timestamp(0)... but then when do we update this to the correct time? And whens a safe place to do that? If we do it too soon then we haven't fixed anything. Which is way trying recreate the bug would be nice to have.. or just don't merge None over epoch.

.zuul.yaml.message: I would prefer to not cap tox here and let the jobs running with tox 4.

I'd rather have them capped.
It may be overabundance of caution on my part. But I'm not really comfortable,
trusting whatever next version of tox might bring. Especially since there were multiple new releases happening for the 4.* this week.

Simply put, if we had conditions like these implemented centrally in the CI, there wouldn't be a need to file dozens of patches fixing various issues.
So I'd rather err on side of caution here, and keep the caps if possible.

zuul.d/project-templates.yaml.message: I'm not sure the use of vars in a project-template like this will do what you intend it to do. The intention is that the jobs within this template will have tox pinned to '<4', but a project-template applies to the entire project instead. This means that every project that has one or more of these templates applied to it will get tox pinned to <4 for every job they run regardless of branch.

specs/2023.1/approved/virtio_packedring_.message:
this is very anti cloud.

if the ring layout is something that the guest driver can configure when packed ring fromat is advertiesed then we should not have any config option.

we should enable the capablity advertisement at both the qemu/libvirt level and the placment/scheduler level.


what we should do is add a new standard trait COMPUTE_NET_VIRTIO_PACKED
on hypervisors that meet the qemu and libvirt requirements the compute agent will
report that new trait to placement.

where the local hypervisor supports packed format the feature bit should be always enabled so that the guest can negociate teh ring layout.

as an end user that requires packed format for my VNF or application i can upload an image with a required trait request via the image properites.

as an operator i can simiarly use required or forbidin traits in the flavor to 
provide affinity and anti affinity.


the largest chalange i see with this or the config driven approch is live migrations.

the virtio ring format and feature bit in general are not allowed to change during a llive migration. more specificially the source and destination host must both support the negociated feature set. the soucce node gets that for free via the inital feature negociation in the guest when the vm is booted. the destintaiton requirement must be ensure by the schduler/placement and it will be validated by qemu/libvirt when we invoke the lower level live migration.


that means that if we have a vm that has packed format negocation enabled we need to be able to ensure we select host where that can also be enabled.

as far as i am aware there is no way to detect from libvirt what virtio fetures were negocated in the guest and we cant ask libvirt what virtio features are supported by the host vhost backend.


we have encountered issues in this regrad in the past where adding the mtu to the libvirt xml changes the virtio feature bitmask form a 32bit int to a 64bit int.

when we first started adding the mtu it broke live migation because we did not detect if the running vm had the mtu element and uncontionally added it when we live migrated.

that worked fine for vms booted on the current release but broke live migrtion for
vm booted on the previous release and there for boke updates.

adding a config option is one way to work around that but its a bad one as it add operational complexity and still has upgrade impacts if you ever want to change the default or explictly set it to another value.

so to make live migration and upgrades work we need to be carful to ensure we know if a vm has been booted with support for packed format.

we normally do that via and image property.
for example we enable virtio-net multiqueue support via an image property or flavor extra spec.

if we were to make this configurable we would need to do that via a flaovr/image property not via a host level config option.

this however is quite a low level option to expsoe to an enduser/cloud operator and 
really is not something that likely should be exposed.

if we can instead detect this cabplity and automatically enable it where possible that would be better.

so the main question i have is if we were to resolve the migration/upgrade problem
is there a reason why we should not always enable this feature transparently and make it uncondtional from a user/operator level . (with some caveats for upgrades)

Few notes:
- I don't see a single reason not to have this enabled, and leave it to VM to decide the preferred layout.
- There is no reliable way to know the negotiated option. Furthermore, nothing stops the VM from unbinding the driver at some point and then re-binding with different layout selected.
- I agree that going the "trait" way is best for now. Should we take a jab and make a change PR, or should be wait for more community input?

we have extened the spec freeze until next thursday so technially the spec coudl be improved and reviewd in that time but it proably wont happen until next cycle

if you want to start working on an implemenation that is ok but note that this really is proably not going to get merged until the B/2023.2 cycle

the main thing you need to ensure is that if a vm is booted on an non upgraded node it can live migrate to an upgraded node.

if its booted on an upgraded nodes its ok if it cannot migrate to a non upgraded node. with that said its preferable if that still works too.

for upgraded nodes the migration code that updates the xml should ensure that if the feature is not enabeld in the orginal xml its not enabled in the updated xml.

however on cold migrate/normal boot its fine to enabel the feature automatically when runnign through the upgraded code path.

this need to detail how upgrade will be supported.

specifical as i noted above how live migration between an non upgraded host and an upgraded host will be supported. including back and fort migration.

back and forth migration is where a vm is booted on a non upgraded host and then migrated to an upgraded host and then back to the orginal host without reboooting the vm.

we test this in the grenade job to ensure that durign a roling upgrade operators can move vms around to enable the upgrade without workload downtime.

if the vm is not rebooted we do not expect the new feature ot be enable even when movign to/form the upgrade host.

you will need to provide functional tests to test thsi too.

the way this shoudl be enabled is for new spawns on upgraded hosts.
such as boot, cold migrate, unshleve, resize, evacuate or hard_reboot.
